title: About
text: My name is Josh Gubbels and I am a senior at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. I am double majoring in Sports Media and Communications & Broadcasting with a minor in Entrepreneurship.

title: Is Jamal Murray An Underrated Point Guard?
text:
When people bring up the top point guards in the league today they talk about SGA, Luka Doncic, Steph Curry, Jalen Brunson, etc. All these point guards are elite, but does Jamal Murray deserve to be included in this list of point guards?
When evaluating a point guards play I think it is crucial that you look at these three stats: points, assists, and field goal percentage.
So now lets look to see where Jamal Murray ranks up against other point guards in the league with the previously stated stat fields.


Code
library(tidyverse)

nba24stats <- read_csv("~/Desktop/spmc_350_fall_2025_gubbels/2024_top150_nba_stats_final.csv")

nba24pg <- nba24stats |>
  filter(PTS > 15) |>
   filter(Pos == "PG")

nuggets <- nba24pg |>
  filter(
    Player == "Jamal Murray"
  )

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=nba24pg, aes(x=reorder(Player, PTS), weight=PTS)) +
  geom_bar(data=nuggets, aes(x=reorder(Player, PTS), weight=PTS), fill="red") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="PTS", 
    title="Murray sits near the middle of the pack", 
    subtitle="Jamal averaged over 20 points a game which is still very good for a point guard.", 
    caption="Source: Pro Basketball Reference | By Josh Gubbels"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Jamal is right below the middle point in that chart, but averaging 20 points a game is still a very good stat to have.
Since we saw how many points he averages a game, I think looking at how well he shoots the ball is a good next step.
Now we will compare the shooting percentage of Jamal to some of the other elite point guards like: Steph Curry, Shai Gilgeous, James Harden, Trae Young, etc.


Code
library(tidyverse)

jm <- read_csv("~/Desktop/spmc_350_fall_2025_gubbels/jamal_murray_yearly_stats.csv")

cc <- read_csv("~/Desktop/spmc_350_fall_2025_gubbels/cade_cunningham_yearly_stats.csv")

sga <- read_csv("~/Desktop/spmc_350_fall_2025_gubbels/shai_gilgeous _alexander_yearly_stats.csv")

sc <- read_csv("~/Desktop/spmc_350_fall_2025_gubbels/stephen_curry_yearly_stats.csv")

ty <- read_csv("~/Desktop/spmc_350_fall_2025_gubbels/trae_young_yearly_stats.csv")

jh <- read_csv("~/Desktop/spmc_350_fall_2025_gubbels/james_harden_yearly_stats.csv")

ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=jm, aes(x=Season, y=FGPCT), color="red") + 
  geom_line(data=cc, aes(x=Season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=sga, aes(x=Season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") + 
  geom_line(data=sc, aes(x=Season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") + 
  geom_line(data=ty, aes(x=Season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") + 
  geom_line(data=jh, aes(x=Season, y=FGPCT), color="grey") +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(.300, .600)) +
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Assists", 
    title="Murray shoots better than some of the league greats", 
    subtitle="Even though he does not have as many points as these other guards, he shoots the ball more effectively than most of them.", 
    caption="Source: Pro Basketball Reference | By Josh Gubbels"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Now that we saw that Murray shoots at a very high rate, we will look into how his assists per game are compared to the other point guards.
Being able to facilitate the ball around to your teammates is one of the most important jobs as a point guard, so lets see how good of a job Jamal does.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(ggrepel)

nba24stats <- read_csv("~/Desktop/spmc_350_fall_2025_gubbels/2024_top150_nba_stats_final.csv")

set.seed(1234)

nba24pg <- nba24stats |> 
  filter(AST > 3.0) |>
  filter(Pos == "PG")

jm <- nba24pg |> 
  filter(Player == "Jamal Murray")


ggplot() + 
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=nba24pg, 
    aes(x=Pos, y=AST), color="grey") + 
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=jm, 
    aes(x=Pos, y=AST), color="red") + 
  geom_text_repel(
    data=jm, 
    aes(x=Pos, y=AST, label=Player))+
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Assists", 
    title="Murray still sitting in the middle of the bunch", 
    subtitle="Jamal is not putting up huge assist numbers, but isnt too far behind the rest with a few outliers.", 
    caption="Source: Pro Basketball Reference | By Josh Gubbels"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









In conclusion, I do not think that Jamal Murray is underrated. Even though he will have a game here and there where he goes off for 45 or more points, I think that he gets the right amount of hype to his name.
His assists per game are not the best, but when you have a guy like Nikola Jokić on your team you’re assist load goes down. The Nuggets also are a very pass heavy offense with many of their players getting involved in the assists game, and also contributing in points.

title: Is Spencer Rattler Actually A Bad Quarterback?
text:
The New Orleans Saints are one of the worst teams in the NFL. Many blame it on the quarterback, but is that really the true reason why they are always losing?
Spencer Rattler has a an abysmal record of 1-12 as a starter in the NFL. Does this record truly represent him as a quarterback?
Let’s take a look at where Rattler’s QBR sits alongside the other starting quarterbacks.


Code
library(tidyverse)

nflqbstats <- read_csv("~/Desktop/spmc_350_fall_2025_gubbels/nfl_passing_stat_leaders.csv")

startingqbs <- nflqbstats |> 
  filter(GS > 7) |>
  filter(Pos  == "QB")

saints <- startingqbs |>
  filter(
    Player == "Spencer Rattler"
  )

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=startingqbs, aes(x=reorder(Player, QBR), weight=QBR)) +
  geom_bar(data=saints, aes(x=reorder(Player, QBR), weight=QBR), fill="red") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="QBR", 
    title="Rattler struggles, but isn't as bad as we're told", 
    subtitle="Spencer Rattler isn't an elite quarterback, but he also isn't the worst.", 
    caption="Source: Pro Football Reference | By Josh Gubbels"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Now we see that Rattler definitely wasn’t great with a QBR of 49.1, but his QBR isn’t too far from quarterbacks like Aaron Rodgers and Bo Nix. Both these quarterbacks currently have winning records with Bo Nix and the Broncos being a top team in the AFC.
Since maybe QBR isn’t too accurate of a stat, lets look at where Rattler sits at in the passing yard rankings.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(ggrepel)

nflqbstats <- read_csv("~/Desktop/spmc_350_fall_2025_gubbels/new_passing_yds_leaders.csv")

set.seed(1234)

nflqbstatsfiltered <- nflqbstats |> 
  filter(YDS > 1000) |>
  filter(Pos == "QB")

sr <- nflqbstats |> 
  filter(Player == "Spencer Rattler")


ggplot() + 
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=nflqbstatsfiltered, 
    aes(x=Pos, y=YDS), color="grey") + 
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=sr, 
    aes(x=Pos, y=YDS), color="red") + 
  geom_text_repel(
    data=sr, 
    aes(x=Pos, y=YDS, label=Player))+
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Passing Yards", 
    title="Rattler still doesn't impress in passing yards", 
    subtitle="Rattler is a little higher in the ranks here, but he is still in the lower third of quarterbacks.", 
    caption="Source: Pro Football Reference | By Josh Gubbels"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Rattler is currently sitting at 24 out of 32 quarterbacks in the passing yards column. He is sitting right above quarterbacks such as Lamar Jackson, Jaxson Dart, and Justin Fields.
Again not good by any means, but he also isn’t the worst of them all.
Now we finally will look at Rattler’s touchdown to interception ratio compared to the other starting quarterbacks.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)

nflqbstats <- read_csv("~/Desktop/spmc_350_fall_2025_gubbels/new_passing_yds_leaders.csv")

tdint <- nflqbstats |>
  filter(Pos == "QB") |>
  filter(GS > 5)

ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=tdint, 
    aes(y=reorder(Player, TD), x=TD, xend=Int),
    size = 2,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "green",
    colour_xend = "red")+
  labs(
    x="TD/INT", 
    y="", 
    title="Rattler is not a standout quarterback", 
    subtitle="Spencer Rattler doesn't have a lot of touchdowns, but also doesn't have very many interceptions.", 
    caption="Source: Pro Football Reference | By Josh Gubbels"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









As we can see Spencer Rattler isn’t throwing a lot of touchdowns or interceptions. On the bright side of things he has a positive touchdowns to interceptions ratio unlike Geno Smith and Cam Ward.
Many can make the excuses of bad play calling, or the fact that the Saints have the 28th ranked rushing offense in the NFL. With such a bad rushing game it can be hard to move the ball in the air.
The Saints defense can also use some improvement in being ranked 21st in rushing defense and 23rd in points allowed per game. When you aren’t able to stop another teams offense it can be hard for your own offense to keep up.
At the end of the day Spencer Rattler isn’t a franchise quarterback, but he could be a really good backup with the right team and coaching staff around him.
